<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="" rend="inline">For why a gods name</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">– thus he proves that he was word conscious, an artist,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">aware of the <del>possibilities, of the limitations</del> of his medium.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>Its</del> <del>He</del> <del>The</del> <add place="above">aware that</add> words, not paint, not music; words themselves.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He To be thus aware of language, the writer must</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">have a past behind him, just as the historian <add place="above">must</add>, in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">order to see the present moment, must <add place="above">set it against</add> the past <add place="above">in counter [illeg.]</add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">behind him. <del>There must be a golden age; the</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>must be corrupt, degenerate, fallen.</del> <del>But</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The golden age of English was to <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs> the age of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">of thine owne spirit which doth in me survive</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">against the language itself, its decay, since</l>
